wikitext.*:
'''Drúwaith Iaur''' also called the '''Old Púkel-wilderness'''<ref name="FurtherNotes">{{UT|12b}}</ref> or '''Old Púkel-land'''<ref name="Note13">{{UT|12c}}, note 13</ref><ref>{{VT|42a}}, entry '''''Lefnui''''', p. 14</ref> was a region of dark woods<ref name="VT42">{{VT|42a}}, entry '''''Gwathló''''', p. 9</ref> in the mountains of the promontory of [[Andrast]]<ref name="FurtherNotes" /> (a southwestern outlier of the [[White Mountains]]) on their northern<ref>[[Christopher Tolkien]], [[General Map of Middle-earth]], label "Druwaith Iaur (Old Pukel-land)" added by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in green colour</ref> and northwestern side<ref>{{UT|West}}</ref>.

Drúwaith Iaur was one of two regions in the White Mountains where the [[Drúedain]] lived. They settled there in the [[First Age]] after they had crossed the river [[Anduin]] (probably near [[Cair Andros]]) from the east and continued to live there secretly at the time of the [[War of the Ring]] in the [[Third Age]].<ref name="FurtherNotes" /> Drúwaith Iaur was never occupied by the [[Númenóreans]],<ref name="FurtherNotes" /> not considered to be a part of the realm of Gondor,<ref name="VT42" /> not inhabited by Men of Gondor or of Rohan and seldom visited by them<ref name="FurtherNotes"/>. After the [[Battles of the Fords of Isen]] the Drúedain came out of the caves where they lived and attacked a remnant of the forces of [[Saruman]] that had been driven from the fords to the south.<ref name="Note13" />

==Etymology==
''Drúwaith Iaur'' is a [[Sindarin]] name, consisting of ''drú'' ("wild"), ''[[waith]]'' ("folk, land")<ref>{{HM|RC}}, p. lxiv</ref> and ''[[iaur]]'' ("old").<ref name="VT42" /> In this name the word ''Iaur'' does not mean "original" but "former".<ref name="FurtherNotes" />

It thus could be translated as '''The old wilderness of the Drû-folk'''<ref>{{UT|Index}}, entry ''Drúwaith Iaur''</ref>, '''Old Púkel-wilderness'''<ref name="FurtherNotes" /> or '''Old Púkel-land'''<ref name="Note13" />.
